Umm...the Lituya Bay tsunami wasn't 524 meters tall. The RUNUP was 524 meters, meaning that the water, after crashing onto the shore, flowed uphill under its own momentum and reached as high as 524 meters above sea level. You have to remember that even a small tsunami, say 5 meters high, can affect LAND that is 40+ meters above sea level. All of that mass moving in one direction, the water just keeps on flowing against gravity.* And the impact of topography also matters a great deal...a "small" tsunami, funneled into a narrow fjord or bay, will reach great heights as its energy is directed predominantly in the inland direction (parallel to the length of the fjord/bay). The actual height of the Lituya wave was FAR lower - ~30 meters. Big difference. Now if you told me a 30 meter tsunami was coming, I'd still be terrified...that's PLENTY to cause mayhem if it hits the right area (some EXTREMELY deadly tsunami have been in the 10-15 meter range)...but c'mon. Your researchers should know better...when the Fogo tsunami, 73,000 years ago is talked about as one of the highest tsunamis we know about, and it's 170 meters, there CLEARLY wasn't a tsunami more than 3X as tall as it in the '50s. That's just...context.

*So in the case of the Kilimanjaro comparison and a 1,500 meter wave from the asteroid impact 66 million years ago, that wave may have TOPPED Kilimanjaro, had it existed near the Atlantic coastline back then.

The Krakatoa eruption in the 1800s produced a 37 meter high wave, just a few meters shorter than the Tohoku Tsunami of 2011. Not as tall but still a mega tsunami was the Storegga slide, a massive 3500 cubic km slide off the Norway coast that completely buried the land between Britain, Denmark and the Netherlands, called Doggerland, some 8000 years ago. Much of this land is still just barely below sea levels (5-50 meters) and evidence of stone age settlements and prehistoric artifacts has been found, as well as forestry. This is where most of Europe's oil and gas drilling occurs, and has therefore also been 3D mapped and explored by these companies. Ice melting was mostly to blame as sea levels rose over 100 meters, but the final blow to Doggerland was a mega tsunami.

There're quite a few comments mentioning the Canary Islands (I assume all of us saw that same documentary on megatsunamis when we were younger), including some wondering why it wasn't mentioned in this video. First, keep in mind what is said in the video - megastunamis dissipate quickly and tend to cause far more damage locally. I would encourage you all to look up the latest research on this particular scenario - not only is the old documentary's scenario assuming basically half a mountain dropping in at once, which has been practically ruled out, but even if that scenario is granted, latest models show it dissipating quickly and resulting in ~10 meter waves in specific locations in the Americas (due to wave interference). So, no, New York and Miami almost certainly won't both be wiped out from one giant wave generated from a landslide.

In coastal science there is a distinction between wave height and wave runup elevation. While the wave runup at Lituya Bay may very well have reached 524m in elevation, the truth is that the actual wave height is unknown. It is known, however, that waves can cause runup elevations many times greater than their wave height. Moreover, there is, typically, a positive correlation between runup elevation and wave length, meaning it wouldn't be unreasonable to see tsunami runup elevations on the order of ten (possibly one hundred) times their wave height.

A bit disapointed you didnt mention the Vajont Dam disaster of 1963

On 9 October 1963 a massive landslide of about 260,000,000 cubic metres (340,000,000 cu yd) of forest, earth, and rock fell into the reservoir at up to 110 kilometres per hour (68 mph), completely filling the narrow reservoir behind the dam. The landslide was complete in just 45 seconds, much faster than predicted, and the resulting displacement of water caused 50,000,000 cubic metres (65,000,000 cu yd) of water to overtop the dam in a 250-metre (820 ft) high wave.

Please be a little less sensationalistic.
The initial wave in Nuugaatsiaq created a wave of 90m heigh, but upon hitting the settlement it was only 10m high. Most of Nuugaatsiaq is situated on a very low peninsula with a lenght of roughly 150m a a width of 50m. It is in the perfect spot to be hit by the wave because the width of the fjord decreases towards Nuugaatsiaq (from 6km to 3km) and the landslide was directly in front of the fjord channeling it to Nuugaatsiaq.
None the less scary, but overreporting the numbers decreases awareness of the destructiveness of smaller tsunamis.
Even mudslides with only 1-2m height can cause deaths if they hit a settlement.
If there was a 100m wave at the settlement the would be no evidence left of the settlement at all, probably the peninsula wouldn´t even exist any more.

Additionally the landslide caused the earthquake registered in Nuugaatsiaq, not the impact of the wave.

If you want to see the effects of a really big tsunami you should look at satellite pictures of the worlds deserts. Those directional patters are not caused by wind blown sand, they are the marks of a flood.

I don't think you are explaining this correctly and it is a common mistake I see when people talk about Tsunamis and wave heights. The actual height of the wave is not the total height the water reached in the incident. The height of a wave won't exceed 1.3 times the depth of the water it is traveling in without breaking. So you don't actually have 100 meter or 300 meter heights (as measured from crest of one wave to trough of following wave) but rather you have a volume and force (the amount of energy generated by the sudden displacement of a certain volume of water) of water that is capable of washing up to that height on land, like water spilling out of tub.

Observe the next time you go to a beach and you build a sand castle 10 feet above the waterline as the tide is coming in. A one foot wave with enough force and volume behind it will wash further than 10 feet in elevation and wipe out your two foot high sand castle. Whereas a 5 foot wave without that volume and force behind it will not even reach your sand castle.

(00:20) "The wave, about as tall as the statue of liberty, washed away 11 houses and killed 4 people" Although I certainly in no way am attempting to diminish the tragic impact on those residents of Nuugaatsiaq who survived this catastrophe, but I feel that Scishow has shown great insensitivity with a sensationalist approach that is deliberately misleading., to whit: Although the initial displacement of water immediately adjacent to the landslide may have been 100 meters, at the location of the village the sea likely rose well UNDER 10 meters - still more than enough to account for the damage done, but NOTHING LIKE what a 100 meter wall of water would have done. Even a 30 meter wave would have guaranteed than not a single home or life would have been spared. Please educate without resorting to fear tactics. An unexpected rapid rise in sea levels of 6 feet poses a serious threat to property and human life for northern coastal communities, but videos like this actually hinder the efforts to generate support for prudent action, it's proponents easily tagged as "Chicken Littles" once the "100 m monster waves" hysteria is debunked. Shame on you guys.
